metadata.title: Heel Pain, Posterior
description: Posterior heel pain near the Achilles tendon that is categorized as Achilles insertional tendinopathy or a Haglund’s deformity (bony enlargement of the back of the heel) with or without the presence of retrocalcaneal bursitis(1)

Sever’s disease (calcanealapophysitis) affects the growth plate of the calcaneus in children between the ages of 8 and 14. Repetitive stress and microtrauma cause inflammation of the calcaneus, resulting in posterior heel pain(9)

ICD-10 codes.M77.3: calcaneal spur (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The patient with Achilles insertional tendinopathy presents with chronic aching and tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion. There will be centrally located swelling and possibly the presence of a bony prominence medially and laterally to the Achilles tendon insertion.(1) Increased activity as in walking or running will exacerbate symptoms. For more detailed information regarding Achilles tendinopathy, see Clinical Review …Achilles Tendinopathy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708580
If retrocalcaneal bursitis also is present, the bursa will be inflamed along with a thickened distal Achilles tendon(2) and can be aggravated by pressure from shoe wear(1)

The patient with a Haglund’s deformity presents with tenderness lateral to the Achilles tendon in conjunction with a swollen, prominent projection, also referred to as a “pump bump.”(1) The distal tendon or bursa becomes more susceptible to irritation caused by the protuberance, so shoe wear severely aggravates the condition(2)
Morning pain might also be reported(1)

Children in whom Sever’s disease is diagnosed might present with pain and tenderness around the Achilles tendon of one or both feet. Sever’s disease is more common with physical exercise that includes running or jumping(9) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If a fracture is suspected, careful handling of the area is necessary to avoid aggravating the condition or eliciting excessive pain. Consult with the physician, if needed

risk factors: Wearing shoes with rigid and tight-fitting  heel counters can cause symptoms(1)

Females aged 20–30  years are most commonly affected by this condition.(1) Women’s high-heel  shoes might exacerbate thecondition by placing the ankle in plantarflexion, as in this position the edge of the heel counter is more likely to impingethe retrocalcaneal bursa
Physically active children during their growth spurt period(9)

overall contraindications precautions: Care should be taken to avoid aggravating retrocalcaneal and/or sub-Achilles bursitis during manual mobilization of the Achilles tendon
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

contraindications precautions to examina: If a fracture is suspected, careful handling of the area is necessary to avoid aggravating the condition or eliciting excessive pain. Consult with the physician, if needed

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Can you describe how and when your symptoms first began? -Any recent change in footwear or orthotics? -Any recent change in your daily activities?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed; are they being taken as prescribed?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is usually based on the history and clinical findings. Radiographs to confirm Haglund’s deformity. MRI to assess for soft tissue involvement (bursitis, Achilles tendinosis) and to rule out calcaneal stress fracture(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Is pain worse with a specific activity, time of day, or type of shoe? Does pain increase with ambulation? Weight-bearing  activity usually sharpens the pain. Is there anything that decreases the pain?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. The patient will report symptoms in the heel area behind the foot. Bilateral symptoms are not uncommon
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). The patient will describe an aching pain, with an occasional sense of fullness. A tender, swollen, prominent projection of the heel bone might also be reported
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any preexisting foot or lower extremity condition? Any prior muscle or bone problems?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What is the patient’s primary recreational activity or sport? What is the patient’s occupation and what does his or her day entail? Has training for sport or activity level recently increased, including increased time standing?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Antalgic gait might interfere with daily activities or sports
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate the effectiveness of a heel lift or heel cup, padding, rocker-bottom shoes, or open-back  shoes for pain relief(1)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Is balance impaired due to pain? How is single-leg  balance when compared to the contralateral side? How is proprioception (i.e., Romberg’s test with eyes open versus closed)?
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pedal pulses in affected foot
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for antalgic gait during barefooted ambulation as well as with sport shoes. Is there overpronation during the stance phase of gait in the affected foot? Does the patient toe-walk  to compensate for pain?
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of the ankle plantar flexors and dorsiflexors, foot everters and inverters
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect for signs of abrasion/blistering/callus in posterior heel area
Inspect/palpate posterior heel area for the presence of a bony prominence
Palpate for point tenderness and bogginess in the distal Achilles tendon
Assess pain intensity on palpation and during activity using V AS
relevant tests and measures.posture: Evaluate for alignment of the rearfoot (calcaneus) in barefoot standing (i.e., is the rearfoot inverted, everted, or neutral?). Is there evidence of overpronation (navicular drop test)? Results might indicate need for a trial of foot orthotics. Also evaluate the rearfoot, forefoot, and first toe in subtalar neutral in non-weight  bearing
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ankle, subtalar, hip, and knee ROM. Is ankle ROM in dorsiflexion limited by tight/shortened gastrocnemius-soleus  complex?
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Should be bilaterally equal and normal. However, the presence of a deviation might be indicative of a proximal nerve impingement(1)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Should be bilaterally equal and normal. However, the presence of a deficiency might be indicative of a proximal nerve impingement or diabetic neuropathy(1)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Tinel test to rule out tarsal tunnel entrapment  –A positive squeeze test of the medial/lateral aspects of the heel might indicate Sever’s disease(9)

other: Care should be taken to avoid aggravating retrocalcaneal and/or sub-Achilles  bursitis during manual mobilization of the Achilles tendon
If a fracture is suspected, avoid joint mobilizations and high-impact activities, and/or consult with the physician, if necessary

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Presence of symptoms that interfere with or limit activities of daily living such as walking
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Plantar fasciitis Tarsal tunnel syndrome Sever’s disease Heel pad atrophy Bone cyst Tumor Fracture Consider rheumatoid arthritis if other joint symptoms also are present(1) Consider calcaneal stress fracture if the patient has pain on squeezing lateral and medial sides of calcaneus(1) Low back pain; the heel pain might be of neurogenic origin(1) Diabetic neuropathy
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Podiatrist consult for orthotics and possible surgery in recalcitrant cases(2)
treatment summary: Treatment and management of Sever’s disease in children should follow a period of rest and recovery, followed by stretching and strengthening of the affected foot(9) –Please see Clinical Review…Sever’ s Disease, referenced above, for more detailed information

Authors of an RCT in Israel suggest that deep tissue massage with neural mobilization and stretching (DMS) was significantly more effective in treating posterior heel pain than ultrasound therapy only(10)  –Fifty-six  patients were randomized to either the DMS group or the ultrasound group and were treated 1–2 times per week for a total of 8 treatments over a 6-week  period –Patients in the DMS group were instructed to lie in prone. Deep tissue massage was performed for 10 minutes to the posterior calf muscle groups. Self-stretching  techniques were performed to the calf muscles for 20 seconds followed by a 10-second  rest period 3 times per day for 5 repetitions per stretch. Neural mobilization was performed with a passive straight-leg  raise combined with dorsiflexion using a long belt for assistance –Ultrasound therapy was performed over the painful areas of the heel with a frequency of 1 MHz and intensity of 1.0 W/ cm2 for 3 minutes . resolution of pain and swelling: Mayo Clinical Scoring System modified for posterior heel pain. This scale uses 6 items (pain, activity limitations,footwear/orthotics, heel tenderness, neuropathy, and antalgic gait)(7)
improved balance and proprioception: Balance assessment such as Berg Balance Scale

maintenance or prevention: Avoidance of footwear and activities associated with flare-ups
Continued independent exercises for maintaining flexibility and strength of the gastrocnemius-soleus  complex
Ongoing pain management with ice packs and NSAIDs
Properly warm-up  before exercising or train in warmer conditions(2)
